titles.title: Cross Product and Quaternion Number System

para.para.body: There is a notational convention, used by engineers and physicists, which may make the formula for the cross product a little easier to remember. Let us name the standard coordinate vectors of \RNr[3] as.

Now a vector \Vect{z}=(a,b,c) can be written as \Vect{z} = a \Vect{i} + b \Vect{j} + c \Vect{k} . The formula for the cross product results from

Comment on ‘symbolically’
Let us be clear: Strictly speaking, the proposed determinant does not exist, as the entries in the first column are not numbers. However, nothing can stop us from applying the formula for evaluating (3,3) -determinants to the symbols appearing in the proposed matrix. Magically the formula for the cross product results. Only now we remember that \Vect{i} , \Vect{j} , and \Vect{k} are vectors in \RNr[3] .
evaluating the determinant below along the first column. Here \Vect{x} = (x_1,y_1,z_1) and \Vect{y} = (y_1,y_2,y_3) .

math.display.latex: \aligned \CrssPr{ \Vect{x} }{ \Vect{y} }\ &=\ \det \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} \Vect{i} & x_1 & y_1 \\ \Vect{j} & x_2 & y_2 \\ \Vect{k} & x_3 & y_3 \end{array} \right] \\ &=\ \det \left[ \begin{array}{cc} x_2 & y_2 \\ x_3 & y_3 \end{array} \right]\Vect{i}\ +\ (-1)\det \left[ \begin{array}{cc} x_1 & y_1 \\ x_3 & y_3 \end{array} \right] \Vect{j}\ +\ \det \left[ \begin{array}{cc} x_1 & y_1 \\ x_2 & y_2 \end{array} \right] \Vect{k} \\ &=\ (x_2y_3-x_3y_2 , -(x_1y_3-x_3y_1) , x_1y_2 - x_2y_1) \endaligned

para.para.body: Recalling that, for a square matrix \Mtrx{A} , \det(\Mtrx{A}) = \det(\Mtrx{A}^T) , we can alternatively express the above formula as follows:

math.display.latex: \aligned \CrssPr{ \Vect{x} }{ \Vect{y} }\ &=\ \det \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} \Vect{i} & \Vect{j} & \Vect{k} \\ x_1 & x_2 & x_3 \\ y_1 & y_2 & y_3 \end{array} \right] \\ &=\ \det \left[ \begin{array}{cc} x_2 & y_2 \\ x_3 & y_3 \end{array} \right]\Vect{i}\ +\ (-1)\det \left[ \begin{array}{cc} x_1 & y_1 \\ x_3 & y_3 \end{array} \right] \Vect{j}\ +\ \det \left[ \begin{array}{cc} x_1 & y_1 \\ x_2 & y_2 \end{array} \right] \Vect{k} \\ &=\ (x_2y_3-x_3y_2 , -(x_1y_3-x_3y_1) , x_1y_2 - x_2y_1) \endaligned

para.para.body: The (3,3) -determinant above has been evaluated along its first row.
Advanced Information We sketch how the cross product can be defined using multiplication of quaternion numbers.
Write an element (a,b,c,d) of \RNr[4] as a + b \Vect{i} +c \Vect{j} + d \Vect{k} .
Define addition of quaternion numbers by

math.display.latex: \aligned &(a + b \Vect{i} + c \Vect{j} + d \Vect{k})\ +\ (w + x \Vect{i} + y \Vect{j} + z \Vect{k})\ = \\ &\qquad (a+w) + (b+x) \Vect{i} + (c+y)\Vect{j} + (d+z)\Vect{k} \endaligned

para.para.body: Define multiplication of quaternion numbers by

math.display.latex: \aligned &(a + b \Vect{i} + c \Vect{j} + d \Vect{k})\cdot (w + x \Vect{i} + y \Vect{j} + z \Vect{k})\ = \\ &\qquad (aw-bx-cy-dz) + (ax+bw+cz-dy) \Vect{i} + (ay+cw-bz+dx)\Vect{j} + (az+dw+by-cx)\Vect{k} \endaligned

para.para.body: Identify \Vect{x} = (x,y,z) in \RNr[3] with the purely imaginary quaternion number x \Vect{i} + y \Vect{j} + z \Vect{k} .
